f4ea20ae05d2da565e774193265e2df2 (00:47): why does gvim not seem to wanna be maximized?
f4ea20ae05d2da565e774193265e2df2 (00:47): it resizes itself to almost fullscreen instead, but that looses its original geometry.
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (00:48): operating system? window manager?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (00:48): gui behavior is gui dependent
f4ea20ae05d2da565e774193265e2df2 (00:48): standard KDE
f4ea20ae05d2da565e774193265e2df2 (00:48): well no other window does that. just gvim.
0c40c1bf00d55d35ab17baf2cbec36f8 (00:48): How are you telling it to maximize?
78934bd80782f14536272b6b4da676ee (00:48): ironfroggy: I had that too :)
f4ea20ae05d2da565e774193265e2df2 (00:48): it maximizes, and then it automatically restores itself and resizes the window to just under my desktop size.
f4ea20ae05d2da565e774193265e2df2 (00:49): deryni: double clicking the titlebar.
78934bd80782f14536272b6b4da676ee (00:49): ironfroggy: it resizes itself onto a line boundary
78934bd80782f14536272b6b4da676ee (00:49): oh, I don't know why, I just know it did :)
78934bd80782f14536272b6b4da676ee (00:50): I gave up with gvim, didnt' like how the mouse moved around the cursor when I clicked about, went back to plain ol' vim
0c40c1bf00d55d35ab17baf2cbec36f8 (00:50): That sounds like gvim not playing nicely with kde.
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (00:50): pookey, :help 'mouse'
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (00:51): you can have either behavior in terminal or gui
0c40c1bf00d55d35ab17baf2cbec36f8 (00:51): Applications based on characters often specify resize increments, since having half a character on screen is useless.
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (00:51): ironfroggy, can you maximize xterm?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (00:51): not konsole, xterm
0c40c1bf00d55d35ab17baf2cbec36f8 (00:51): Using the same font?

78934bd80782f14536272b6b4da676ee (00:51): tpope: oh, that's nice - I'll have to remember that.. .however... my other reason for using vim mostly is 95% of the files I edit are on remote machines, but I appreciate the tip!
f4ea20ae05d2da565e774193265e2df2 (00:52): yes, xterm not konsole.
0c40c1bf00d55d35ab17baf2cbec36f8 (00:52): ironfroggy: Using the same font and font size?
f4ea20ae05d2da565e774193265e2df2 (00:52): so its a font issue? not to sound rude, but wow thats dumb.
0c40c1bf00d55d35ab17baf2cbec36f8 (00:52): I didn't say that.
f4ea20ae05d2da565e774193265e2df2 (00:52): it breaks the ability to restore back to the original window size.
0c40c1bf00d55d35ab17baf2cbec36f8 (00:52): I asked a question.
f4ea20ae05d2da565e774193265e2df2 (00:52): no, its not the same font size.
0c40c1bf00d55d35ab17baf2cbec36f8 (00:52): Try xterm with the same font/fontsize and see how it behaves.
0c40c1bf00d55d35ab17baf2cbec36f8 (00:53): It will likely also not be fullscreen, it may or may not break in the same way.
f4ea20ae05d2da565e774193265e2df2 (00:53): so is there a way around it?
0c40c1bf00d55d35ab17baf2cbec36f8 (00:53): It depends on what the problem is.
f4ea20ae05d2da565e774193265e2df2 (00:54): does it _have_ to be sized in a such a way that the client area is a multiple of the font dimensions?
0c40c1bf00d55d35ab17baf2cbec36f8 (00:55): Yes (unless you override the x properties, or tell your wm to ignore them), but that shouldn't cause what you are seeing.

0c40c1bf00d55d35ab17baf2cbec36f8 (00:56): It should just only take up as much room as it can use and leave the rest empty. The fact that it is unmaximizing and then resizing itself to that large is a bug, likely an interaction bug between gvim/gtk+ and kde.
0c40c1bf00d55d35ab17baf2cbec36f8 (00:56): Well, "bug".
abe59155aa41ae19e4ea964e9dd4b200 (00:56): http://www.bagdadsoftware.de")
